FacilityName: President Street Water Quality Control Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
President Street Water Reclamation Plant (WRP) has served the City of Savannah and a small portion of Chatham County since 1973. To ensure proper treatment of the wastewater prior to discharging to the savannah river, chlorine is injected into effluent flow to disinfect and kill pathogens that may be contained in the effluent flow. The disinfection feed rates varies from 100 lbs. per day to 700 lbs. per day, depending on the effluent quality and demand. The chlorine control system has been upgraded with four additional cylinder mounted vacuum regulators. These units will stop chlorine gas flow if there is a break in the supply line, mitigating offsite impact.

There are several chlorine leak detectors in the chlorine system located in the process area and storage site perimeters, when a chlorine leak is detected, the leak detectors activate visual and audible alarms to alert the plant personnel.

Responsibilities:
The Treatment Administrator has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Process Management Plan is followed, reviewed and updated.

The Operation Superintendent will be responsible for Employee Involvement, Employee Training, Emergency Preparedness, Compliance Audits, Process Hazard Analysis, Management  Changes, Process Safety Information, and Operating Procedures and Practices.

The Maintenance Superintendent will be responsible for Contractors, Pre-startup Safety, Mechanical Integrity, Monthly Maintenance Scheduling and Non- routine Work Authorization.

To reduce the risk and magnitude of potential releases, written procedures for the safe handling and operation of the chlorination system have been implemented as well as system upgrades. 

In addition, work performed on equipment subject to cause a release requires a minimum of two personnel; personnel are also required to wear a Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) throughout the course of work associated with chlorination equipment. Any major work performed on the chlorination system is limi

ted to daytime only to reduce the possibility of a chlorine release and to ensure sufficient personnel are immediately available should a release occur. 

To date, there has been no chlorine released from the President Street Water Reclamation Plant.

The Savannah Fire Department Haz-mat division has surveyed the chlorine system and storage area. The Haz-Mat division is located about five minutes from the President Street WQCP.
